text: My father was born in Boston. His
parents immigrated from Ireland to the
United States uh prior to 1900. He was
born in Boston in 1900. He never knew
his parents. Uh we don't know much about
the history, but apparently his mother
died shortly thereafter. The father
couldn't care for the children. And so
my father and his siblings were all
placed in orphanages in the Boston area.
So my father grew up in an orphanage in
central Boston. And then back in those
days, it's quite an interesting story
which I didn't learn until after my
father's death because he never spoke
about his uh early years. Uh back in
those days, the nuns who ran these
orphanages used to take these uh kids
out on the weekends to Catholic parishes
in the rural parts of New England. And
at the end of the Sunday mass, a group
of children would be lined up in the
front of the church at the altar rail
and anybody who wanted to adopt a child
would just take one by the hand and walk
out the door with them. As you can see,
there's a huge potential for abuse and
there was abuse, I think, particularly
in the rural areas. Uh but in that
manner, my father was adopted in Bango,
Maine by an elderly, childless couple.
They then moved shortly thereafter to
Waterville, Maine, which is where I grew
up, and where my father grew up with his
adoptive parents. Uh they it was a slum.
They were very poor. Uh my grandparents
ran a small store of some kind. And uh
uh back in those days the textile mills
were booming and uh a lot of immigrants
came in to work the textile mills not
just in Waterville but throughout
northern New England. The workers tended
to be uh largely French Canadian who
were immigrating from Quebec. That's a
whole different story. Very interesting.
But they immigrated to many cities in
northern New England, particularly those
which were on rivers and had textile and
footwear mills. Uh and my mother's uh
two sisters uh uh preceded her as
immigrants from Lebanon to the United
States and they both ended up in Maine,
one of them in Waterville. So when my
mother immigrated in
19 20 when she was 18 years old uh she
went to live with her sister in
Waterville
uh which happened to be in the same
tenement worker workingass area that my
father and his parents lived in. So my
parents met and married in that fashion.
Uh back in those days the emphasis was
on assimilation. Uh although my father
was Irish, he had blue eyes and sandy
brown hair and and very light-skinned.
Uh he never he didn't know he was from
Ireland until later in his life. And he
never once mentioned the word. His
adoptive parents had themselves
immigrated from Lebanon to the United
States many years ago. And there was a
sort of a a colony of immigrants uh some
from Quebec, some from other parts of
the world, but a group from Lebanon. And
so at growing up, my mother who couldn't
read or write and spoke uh very accented
and fractured English uh
uh communicated with my father
frequently in Arabic. My father,
although he had no education, he worked
all of his life, learned to speak French
fluently because of the influence of the
area. And so their communication was in
Arabic. My father spoke a good bit of
French. And uh our whole uh growing up
was uh to assimilate and become
American. That sort of was the ideal of
my my parents. It was we were very poor
but never any sense of deprivation. My
father worked uh primarily as a laborer
for a local utility. When he lost that
job, uh he was out of work for about a
year. That was a very tough year my
senior year in high school. And then he
got a job as a janitor at Kobe College,
which is in our hometown of Waterville.
My mother on the very first day she
arrived as an 18-year-old girl got a job
in the textile mill. There was a mill
almost directly adjacent to this uh
tenement area and she spent almost all
of her adult life working in one or one
of several textile mills that ring the
area. Uh she worked a night shift for
about 40
years. No, no, I I had absolutely no
idea. I was uh I was young and naive and
ignorant and uncertain and insecure. I I
I did fairly well in school. Uh I didn't
I don't think I applied myself very
well, but I was kind of fortunate. And
so I graduated from high school when I
was 16 years old and from college when I
was 20. uh most of my life was early
life was devoted to fending off an
inferiority complex because my three
older brothers were great athletes and I
was not I was not as good as my
brothers. In fact, I often say jokingly
that I was not as good as anybody else's
brother. Uh and so very early as a young
boy, I began to be known around our
little town as Johnny Mitchell's kid
brother, the one who isn't any good.
Well, you can guess what that does to a
young guy. So uh uh that was my life
early and as I said in in my earlier
comments my father lost his job when I
was a senior in high school. It was a
very tough year. He had a very tough
time with it. Uh and so there was quite
a bit of uncertainty about whether or
not I would go on to college. My three
older brothers had gone on, two with
sports scholarships and one had uh had
gone through a Navy training program in
the last years of the Second World War.
So it wasn't quite certain in my case,
but by a number of accidents that worked
to my good fortune, I ended up going to
Bowden, a really great school. And uh
but even then I I never thought of a
political career. That didn't come till
quite a bit later in my life.
